title: PM Agrees with Abe on Need to Improve Bilateral Relations
text:
Lee and Abe talked for just about 20 minutes and agreed they could "no longer stand idly by" while diplomatic relations between the two neighboring countries worsened, according to Vice Foreign Minister Cho Sei-young, who also sat down at the meeting.

Prime Minister Lee Nak-yon met Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe on Thursday after attending the enthronement ceremony of Japan's new emperor Naruhito the previous day.

Lee urged Abe to "expedite a wide range of mutual exchanges, including talks between leaders of the two countries" to find a solution to a deepening spat over compensation for wartime Korean forced-labor victims. Abe responded by saying that the two countries "should continue to talk."

They also agreed on the importance of bilateral and trilateral cooperation involving the U.S. in dealing with North Korea.

However, Lee and Abe did not see eye to eye over the issue of compensation for Korean victims of forced labor during World War II, which sparked the spat between the two neighbors, and again reiterated their respective positions and differences.

Seoul remains of the opinion that the government cannot interfere in judicial rulings here, while Tokyo insists that all compensation claims were settled under lump sum reparations in 1965.

Lee also proposed a summit with President Moon Jae-in, but Abe stayed mum. Lee presented Abe with a personal letter from Moon before the meeting ended.
description: PM Agrees with Abe on Need to Improve Bilateral Relations
